title: What is the difference between I am an English teacher or I am a teacher of English? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a fine-tuning consideration here, but I assume that this is what you’re asking for. Here are the differences as they appear to me — I’m not saying this is definitive for all English speakers universally. “I am an English teacher” = This is a more typical phrasing and one that an average person might expect if they ask a person who teaches English what it is they do for a living. For example, a conversation might go like this:Bob: So, I’m a programmer at Intel. What is it that you do?English teacher: I’m an English teacher at a local high school.“I am a teacher of English.” This sounds a little foreign or stilted to my ears and somewhat wordy. There’s a distance that’s created between you and your job that doesn’t exist in sentence #1, and if I heard that, I might assume that the speaker either speaks English as a foreign language, teaches English at a department of defense school overseas, or teaches English as a second language. In the second sentence, at least to me, the focus or stress is more on the language itself rather than on the literature or genres within English letters.Hope that helps.

“I am an English teacher” can have two meanings: “I teach subjects related to the English language—English literature, English grammar, and so on.” This is the most common interpretation.“I am a teacher from England. I may teach any subject; ‘English teacher’ refers to my origin.” This is a far less common interpretation, but that’s what it could mean.“I am a teacher of English” would unambiguously mean that the person teaches subjects related to the English language. However, as others have noted, that’s a very formal, unnatural way to express the thought. A much better way would be to say: “I teach English.”
